title: Flashback: Queen Steal the Show at Live Aid
summary: At Live Aid on July 1985, Queen performed a 20-minute set at Wembley Stadium, strategically scheduled to maximize UK viewership.  Facing stiff competition from acts including U2, Dire Straits, and David Bowie, as well as reunions of Led Zeppelin, The Who, Black Sabbath, and Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young, Queen delivered a high-energy performance featuring "Bohemian Rhapsody," "Radio Ga Ga," "Hammer to Fall," "Crazy Little Thing Called Love," "We Will Rock You," and "We Are the Champions."  While many reunion acts underwhelmed, Queen's performance was critically lauded, often cited as stealing the show, leading to a successful 1986 stadium tour—their last with Freddie Mercury.

title: Live Aid at 40:  'I realise how lucky I was to be there' - BBC News
summary: On the 40th anniversary of Live Aid (July 13, 1985), Jane Barclay-Trott and Chris Fowler, two Gloucestershire women, shared their memories of attending the Wembley Stadium concert.  They recall the atmosphere, performances by Queen (highlighted as a standout), David Bowie, and Status Quo, and the impactful famine relief film shown during the event.  The women remember the ticket price (£5 plus a £20 donation), the diverse crowd, and the shared sense of purpose surrounding Bob Geldof's initiative to raise funds for Ethiopian famine relief.  The BBC will re-broadcast the concert and feature a related documentary series.

Inspired by Michael Buerk's October 1984 BBC News reports on the Ethiopian famine and the success of the Band Aid single "Do They Know It's Christmas?", conceived by Bob Geldof and Midge Ure,  Geldof organized Live Aid.  The single, recorded on November 25, 1984, at Sarm West Studios, raised £8 million.  The idea for a large-scale concert originated with Boy George of Culture Club, following a December 22, 1984, performance.  Geldof envisioned a dual-venue concert (Wembley and Madison Square Garden) broadcast globally, a plan requiring significant negotiation with artists, as confirmed by production manager Andy Zweck.

Live Aid's organization involved Harvey Goldsmith (Wembley concert) and Michael C. Mitchell (US leg).  Bob Geldof spearheaded the event.  Tony Verna secured John F. Kennedy Stadium in Philadelphia, a three-hour prime-time ABC slot, and an ad-hoc US network reaching 85% of TVs, leveraging connections with Mayor Wilson Goode and ABC's John Hamlin.  Verna, co-executive producer with Hal Uplinger (also involved in the creation of instant replay), designed the satellite schematic. Uplinger conceived a four-hour edited video for areas lacking satellite access.

title: Six things that almost derailed Live Aid - BBC Bitesize
summary: Live Aid, a global concert held on July 13, 1985, at Wembley Stadium (London) and JFK Stadium (Philadelphia), was spearheaded by Bob Geldof and Midge Ure to raise funds for Ethiopian famine relief.  Despite initial skepticism, over 1.5 billion people viewed the event.  Many artists' participation wasn't confirmed until shortly before the event; Queen's involvement, for example, was initially announced prematurely.  The concert faced criticism for excluding Black British artists, according to *The Voice*.  Phil Collins famously performed at both locations, traveling via Concorde. Technical issues included a mismatched audio and video feed from Moscow and sound problems for U2 and Paul McCartney.

title: 33 years later, Queen’s Live Aid performance is still pure magic
summary: Holly Thomas's CNN article reflects on Queen's legendary Live Aid performance on July 13, 1985.  Despite facing pre-performance pessimism and past controversies, including a South Africa tour, Freddie Mercury delivered a captivating 21-minute set, including "Bohemian Rhapsody" and "Radio Ga Ga," captivating a global audience of 1.9 billion.  The article highlights Mercury's charisma and stage presence, supported by Brian May, Roger Taylor, and John Deacon.  The performance, viewed by the author since childhood, is praised for its energy and theatrical elements, ultimately revitalizing Queen's career and solidifying their legacy.  Mercury's death from AIDS in 1991 is mentioned, but the article focuses on his remarkable Live Aid triumph.

title: Details of the four known broadcasts for the Live Aid (July 13th, 1985)
summary: Live Aid, held on July 13, 1985, was broadcast globally, reaching a larger audience than the 1969 moon landing.  Broadcasting varied significantly by region and channel. The BBC's European feed, though monochrome, included interviews and commentary,  while a stereo simulcast aired on BBC Radio 1.  Other European channels, receiving a "clean feed" from the BBC, showed some footage absent from the BBC broadcast.  In the US, ABC aired the final three hours, hosted by Dick Clark, while MTV provided a stereo broadcast with more comprehensive coverage but numerous commercials.  MTV also aired an edited version of "Oz for Africa" the night before.  A 10-hour BBC retrospective, including new interviews, aired in July 1995 and was shown on VH1 in the US.  A complete viewing of Live Aid today requires access to multiple sources.

Several prominent artists declined participation in Live Aid (July 13, 1985), organized by Bob Geldof.  Bruce Springsteen regretted missing the event due to underestimating its scale, while Michael Jackson was committed to his *Bad* album. Prince contributed a pre-recorded video.  Boy George feared his band, Culture Club, would be inadequate, and Huey Lewis and the News withdrew due to concerns about aid distribution.  Annie Lennox was ill, Cliff Richard had prior commitments, and Deep Purple's participation was thwarted by Ritchie Blackmore.  Marillion, Madness, and UB40 were not invited, while Thin Lizzy had disbanded. Roger Waters performed solo, and Rush's absence was attributed to the event's "in-crowd" nature.  Neil Peart criticized some participants' motives.

title: The Real Bohemian Rhapsody Ending: What Actually Happened To Queen After Their Live Aid Performance
summary: Following their iconic 1985 Live Aid performance, Queen continued their success.  They embarked on the Magic Tour (June 1986-August 1986),  playing 26 cities and culminating in a large Budapest concert (July 27, 1986) for 80,000 fans – the largest by a Western band in Communist Europe.  The tour supported their album *A Kind of Magic* (June 2, 1986), six songs of which featured in the *Highlander* soundtrack.  Band members pursued solo projects; Freddie Mercury released *Mr. Bad Guy* (April 1985), and Brian May collaborated with Eddie Van Halen.  Mercury's 39th birthday party footage appeared in his "Living on My Own" video.  He also collaborated with Montserrat Caballé, resulting in the song "Barcelona" (1987), featured at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics.  Mercury died in 1991.

Live Aid, held in 1985, raised $127 million (equivalent to $370 million in 2024) for famine relief in Africa, significantly impacting humanitarian aid and Western foreign policy.  Bob Geldof's organization, spurred by Michael Buerk's impactful BBC News report, generated a massive surge in public awareness and charitable giving.  The event boosted the careers of many artists, including Queen, whose Live Aid performance was recreated in the 2018 film *Bohemian Rhapsody*.  Key figures like Claire Bertschinger (awarded the Florence Nightingale Medal in 1991 and a Damehood in 2010) and Geldof (knighted in 1986) were recognized for their contributions.  Live Aid's legacy continues with various media projects, including a Disney miniseries (announced November 2023), an IMAX documentary, a jukebox musical (*Just for One Day*) which premiered in February 2024, and a four-part documentary (*Live Aid: When Rock 'n' Roll Took on the World*) released in 2025.

During the July 13, 1985 Live Aid concerts, Bob Geldof's plea for donations, spurred by a disappointing initial £1.2 million raised and amplified by Queen's performance, significantly increased the donation rate to £300 per second.  A Canadian Broadcasting Corporation video depicting starving Ethiopian children, shown after David Bowie's performance, further boosted contributions.  The Republic of Ireland had the highest per capita donation.  A substantial £1 million donation came from Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum.  While initial reports stated £40-£50 million raised, the total is now estimated at around £150 million for famine relief.  The BBC facilitated donations via phone lines and a postal address.

title: Queen's Live Aid Performance: How They Stole The Show
summary: Queen's 21-minute performance at Live Aid on July 13, 1985, at Wembley Stadium is widely considered one of the greatest live concerts ever.  Despite initial hesitation (acknowledged by Brian May in 2019), the band—Freddie Mercury, Brian May, John Deacon, and Roger Taylor—thoroughly rehearsed a five-song setlist at the Shaw Theatre.  Their performance, strategically scheduled for optimal global viewership, included iconic hits like "Bohemian Rhapsody," "Radio Ga Ga," and "We Are the Champions."  The set was lauded by fellow performers, including Elton John, and critics alike, for its energy and connection with the estimated 1.9 billion viewers worldwide.  The concert's success propelled Queen's subsequent album, *A Kind of Magic*, to six million sales and a world tour.  Bob Geldof, Live Aid's organizer, hailed Queen as the best band of the day.

title: Live Aid, 36 Years Later: Celebrating Satellite History | Intelsat
summary: Live Aid, held on July 13, 1985, was a 16-hour benefit concert raising over $125 million for famine relief in Africa.  Featuring acts like Queen, Run DMC, and Elton John, the concert took place simultaneously at Wembley Stadium (London) and JFK Stadium (Philadelphia).  An estimated 1.9 billion people across 150 nations watched via a massive satellite broadcast, utilizing 13 satellites, including five Intelsat satellites—one of the largest satellite link-ups in history.  Producer Hal Uplinger, who received a 1989 Computerworld Smithsonian Award for his work, oversaw the complex logistical operation centered in Philadelphia.

title: Live Aid: The day music changed the world | Sky HISTORY TV Channel
summary: Live Aid, a global charity concert organized by Bob Geldof and Midge Ure on July 13, 1985, raised over $127 million for famine relief in Ethiopia.  Inspired by a BBC documentary, Geldof initially created the Band Aid single "Do They Know It's Christmas?"  The two main concerts, held simultaneously at Wembley Stadium (London) and John F. Kennedy Stadium (Philadelphia), featured iconic artists including Queen, David Bowie, U2, and Led Zeppelin.  The event's success spurred increased celebrity involvement in charity and influenced subsequent large-scale benefit concerts like Live 8.  Live Aid's impact extended beyond fundraising, raising global awareness of poverty and inspiring charitable action.  A musical, "Just For One Day," commemorating the event, ran in London in 2024.

Live Aid, a globally televised concert held on July 13, 1985, was a landmark event.  Richard Skinner opened the BBC's European broadcast, which featured presenters including Andy Kershaw and Janice Long.  Technical challenges included unsynchronized audio and video feeds between London and Philadelphia, resulting in omissions, particularly for the BBC's broadcast.  In the US, ABC aired the final three hours, while MTV provided a separate stereo feed.  Syndicated coverage, handled by Orbis Communications, significantly altered the broadcast sequence to accommodate commercial breaks and prime-time scheduling.  The BBC's use of 12-channel desks, in contrast to the rock industry's more advanced systems, highlighted a disparity in technical capabilities. A ten-hour re-broadcast aired in 1995.
